practiceQuestions.question: What is the correct contracted future form of “you (plural) will eat” in Dholuo?
practiceQuestions.explanation: “ubochiemo” is the correct future contracted form for the second person plural subject.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following best represents the future continuous form of “they will be eating well”?
practiceQuestions.explanation: “Gibiro ga chiemo maber” uses the habitual/future progressive marker ‘ga’ correctly.

practiceQuestions.question: In the sentence “Abiro chiemo,” which part of the construction indicates the future tense?
practiceQuestions.explanation: “abiro” contains the auxiliary “biro” marking the future tense with the subject prefix “a-”.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following is the correct literal interpretation of the sentence “Abiro bedo gi nyithindo ariyo”?
options: I will come eat with two children.
I will be with two children.
I come to be with children two.
I go to be with two children.
practiceQuestions.explanation: The sentence literally translates as ‘I come to be with children two,’ reflecting Dholuo word order.

practiceQuestions.question: What does the sentence “Nyaka wanene” imply in terms of grammatical obligation?
options: We should try to see him
practiceQuestions.explanation: “Nyaka” expresses necessity or obligation; “wanene” means ‘we see him’ — so together: ‘We must see him’.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following phrases demonstrates a misuse of the auxiliary “biro”?
practiceQuestions.explanation: “Abiro chiem” is incorrect; ‘chiem’ is not an infinitive or participial form — it should be ‘chiemo’.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the source of the auxiliary “biro” used in Dholuo future constructions?
practiceQuestions.explanation: “Biro” is derived from the verb “bi” (to come), used to form the future tense.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following correctly illustrates a future event happening tomorrow?
practiceQuestions.explanation: “Kiny nadogi” translates to ‘Tomorrow they will come,’ correctly indicating a future action.

practiceQuestions.question: What syntactic property is unique to the use of the auxiliary “biro” in Dholuo?
options: It always follows the main verb
It carries subject and tense agreement
It requires the main verb to be conjugated
It appears only in plural forms
practiceQuestions.explanation: “Biro” inflects for subject agreement and functions as the future auxiliary.

practiceQuestions.question: Why is “bochiemo” considered grammatically valid in Dholuo?
options: It is a present tense verb
It replaces both subject and verb
It’s a contraction of “biro chiemo” and includes subject agreement
It’s a compound word for future continuous
practiceQuestions.explanation: “Bochiemo” is a valid contraction of “biro chiemo” with integrated subject agreement prefix.
